title: Brexit: DUP 'unable to vote' for Boris Johnson's deal
text:
Image copyright AFP Image caption The DUP's Arlene Foster and Nigel Dodds had been in talks with the government

The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) has said its MPs will not vote for Boris Johnson's Brexit plan, hours after the UK and EU agreed a new deal.

It was reached on Thursday before a meeting of EU leaders in Brussels.

But the DUP said it would be "unable" to back the proposals in the Commons as they were not in the best interests of Northern Ireland.

The party's support is seen as crucial if the deal is to pass in Parliament before the 31 October deadline.

In a statement on Thursday, the DUP said the proposals were "not beneficial to the economic wellbeing of Northern Ireland" and undermined the integrity of the union.

It confirmed it would not vote for the deal and said the plan to give the Northern Ireland Assembly a vote on whether to continue following some EU rules would "drive a coach and horses" through the Good Friday peace agreement.

Skip Twitter post by @BBCJayneMcC DUP MP says they haven’t budged from their stance - meaning PM must think he can get the numbers without his Northern Irish allies... — Jayne McCormack (@BBCJayneMcC) October 17, 2019 Report

'Consent is the cornerstone'

The UK and the EU have been working on the legal text of a deal but it will still need the approval of both the UK and European parliaments.

Speaking in Brussels, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier described the consent proposal in the agreement as "a cornerstone of our newly agreed approach".

"Four years after entry into force of the protocol, the elected representatives of Northern Ireland will be able to decide by simple majority whether to continue applying relevant union rules in Northern Ireland or not," he said.

What has the reaction been in NI and the Republic of Ireland?

Speaking in Londonderry, the Northern Ireland Secretary Julian Smith said "we've abandoned nobody" when asked if his government had decided not to rely on the DUP's votes.

"I want to make the case for every MP to get this deal over the line on Saturday to make sure we bring this chapter of Brexit to a close," he told BBC News NI.

Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption The government has not abandoned the DUP, says Northern Ireland Secretary Julian Smith

Taoiseach (Irish Prime Minister) Leo Varadkar, who is in Brussels for the EU summit, said: "It's up to the members of the House of Commons now to decide whether they want a deal."

His deputy Simon Coveney said the deal was worth supporting because it "protects core Irish interests".

Speaking in the Dáil (Irish parliament), Mr Coveney added: "It is a deal that will protect people on this island, it will protect peace on this island, it will protect grade on this island it will ensure there will be no checks."

Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption "This is a big step forward. It is a new deal" - Simon Coveney

Ulster Bank's chief economist Richard Ramsey said the deal was "significantly worse" than the one Theresa May struck with the EU last year - it was subsequently rejected by MPs.

Skip Twitter post by @Ramseconomics A good deal for hard Brexiteers. A bad deal for advocates of a soft Brexit and Remainers. Significantly worse for the NI economy than May's deal. More bureaucracy, red tape & complexity. Adding to the costs of doing business. NI to become a spectator on any UK trade deals? — Richard Ramsey (@Ramseconomics) October 17, 2019 Report

Sinn Féin president Mary Lou McDonald said she welcomed that a new deal had been agreed.

"Any deal can only mitigate the worst effects of Brexit; a least worst option," she added.

"The deal agreed today is complex and wide-ranging and all aspects need to be considered in their entirety."

Ulster Unionist MLA Steve Aiken said Mr Johnson's Brexit deal keeps Northern Ireland in the EU "to all intents and purposes".

He told the BBC's The Nolan Show: "If you were a leave voter in Northern Ireland you'd be asking yourself: 'Is this what I voted for?'

"This has been a disaster for Northern Ireland - the only way we can get out of it is to stay [in the EU]."

Image copyright Dan Kitwood Image caption Boris Johnson was in talks with the DUP at Downing Street on Wednesday

SDLP leader Colum Eastwood made an appeal to the DUP: "Do not shoot this down until we know what it means because we do know what no deal means... a hardening of the border on this island, a threat to our peace process.

"[The DUP has] a responsibility to the farmers, to the business community, to the ordinary community out there to get this resolved," he added.

Alliance Party leader and MEP Naomi Long said she wanted the prime minister to put the deal to the public in a referendum.

"If the DUP are not willing to provide the arithmetic to get a deal through Parliament then I think Boris Johnson would be right to go to the public."

Conservative MP and Brexit supporter Iain Duncan Smith said he would "reserve judgement" on the deal until he had read the detail of it.

He said: "There are issues - if the DUP aren't backing it, what are their reasons for not backing it?"

What does the deal involve for NI?

The Brexit deal struck in Brussels would involve Stormont giving ongoing consent to any special arrangements for Northern Ireland.

It would not be the unionists' veto demanded by the DUP - instead the arrangements could be approved by a straight majority.

Pro-EU parties have a narrow majority at Stormont.

Image copyright AFP Image caption Anti-Brexit protests were held at several points on the Irish border on Wednesday

It would continue to follow EU rules on food safety and product standards.

The DUP has already accepted that Northern Ireland would have to align with some EU rules to avoid a hard border.

Northern Ireland would also leave the EU customs union.

But EU customs procedures would still apply on goods coming into Northern Ireland from Great Britain in order to avoid checks at the border.

Stormont would have to approve those arrangements on an ongoing basis.

Approval would involve a straight-forward majority, which would keep the special arrangements in place for four years.

Image copyright AFP Image caption The issue of the Irish border has been the most contentious in the Brexit talks

Alternatively, if the arrangements are approved by a majority of nationalists and a majority of unionists, they would remain in place for eight years - that would incentivise a cross-community consensus.

If the Northern Ireland Assembly voted to end the arrangements there would be a two-year notice period, during which the UK and the EU would have to agree ways to protect the peace process and avoid a hard border.

There is no fallback position in case the two sides cannot find a solution.

If a vote was not held - by choice or because the assembly was not sitting - then there would be no change and the special arrangements would continue.

The EU believes that replaces the backstop - which would have lasted "unless and until" an alternative was found - with arrangements that are sustainable over time and are democratically supported, as requested by the UK.
description: The DUP says it will not support the PM's plan for NI as it has concerns about customs and consent.
